2. The story behind how they want to impact the world/ communities their working with
3. What the project itself is

messages.content: What does everyone think?
What is your Ethereum wallet address? * should not be compulsory ?
rest all is at its best but eth a problem  @m1guelpf @kevalin

Looks great! 🔥
Link to demo video or attach a deck or something?
add this @m1guelpf  Where do you live now, and where would the organization be based after
Looks good. Maybe questions about people on the team? It is good to know if individual or the team behind?
@kevalin @m1guelpf there should be a different application for company representer . Like I represent https://www.bloodyfast.org/ https://prajnainitiative.org/ https://www.bluewarriors.net/
1st suggest to #Number Q’s like in code/agreement lines to refer momentarily/exactly.

if we are working with DAOs, they generally don't have a headquartered location. And with digital nomads on the rise, more people are transitory so I don't know if it is important to include "where do you live now" and "where would the organization be based after". Thoughts on why to have these questions?
@nicklinck if they are in korth korea
north korea
syria
afganistan
@kevalin
any vulnerably, even in apparently safe/developed areas/countries, so with special requests. Regret, researched something and very very sad pictures.
@nicklinck if we are working with DAOs, they generally don't have a headquartered location. they can put virtual location even if temporary

could we add categorical questions? perhaps what industry (finance, education, healthcare, etc) and type of product (DAO, dapps, mobile, etc) - to easily filter and redirect for a large n of applications
This is outside my knowledge base, can we legally not invest in an entity registered in North Korea, syria or afganistan?
We can invest any how but we need to comply with rules if our organisation is registered in usa
@nicklinck we cannot even invest in iran as well if in usa
+1 this could help with training AI to identify "hot" topics, and would allow SME to look at pitches in their area of expertise. Potentially maybe categories such as B2B and B2C as well

Sam said "we can invest in US entities but form them for projects anywhere in the world." So maybe on the application we can say: 
Are you a US based entity? 
*If not will help you form one. For V.01 we are only investing in US entities.*
@nicklinck great specify it first
Maybe add a link to stripe atlas and explain how they can use the platform to be eligible for investments?
Why eth? Its slow and clunky
before application — who can help fine tune pitch to optimize overall throughput-out/quality?
How about asking: “what resources does your project/company need today in order to be successful?”
@schalkkearney that's what I am trying to say .
@kevalin how about solana @schalkkearney @BeeSee @rx
I agree rx — Solana makes most sense to me.
yes, we can give them options, not compulsory Solana or eth or binance  @BeeSee. but only trustworthy platforms.
additionally L2 becomes more and more popular, powerful and cheaper...
+1 for being stack agnostic
I think sam said he wants to pay with an eth wallet, so we would need eth wallet address on app
@BeeSee @schalkkearney anyhow we need for investments its fine if it takes time . @kevalin

but receiving payment in eth  does not exclude projects  that want to build on other chains, do I understand that correctly?
or we want to keep everything consistent for now: payments, token allocation etc..

messages.content: Thinking Polygon rn
EVM is easy to move fast with
are we restricting applications to one blockchain? because that's a big deal
I don't think we should restrict by blockchain. Doesn't make any sense to me
it also heavily impacts the quantity and quality of applications...
I think we should be open to as many ideas to fund as possible and then have an internal funnelling process
From what I recall, the original idea was not even to restrict to on-chain orgs.
yea but scroll up to read the channel, they are discussing exactly that
Agree with this
Yeah def don't want to do this
We'll invest in projects on the most popular chains
@kevalin we can restrict to most trustworthy chain ?
chains
We'll see. Having a discussion about this tomorrow
There are also layer 1 and interoperability projects that are chain agnostic or multi chain, not sure we should restrict proactively until we see what sorts of opportunities come in
um why would we restrict chains? that makes no sense
would like a rationale  for this before we consider doing it
@rx
i think chain restrictions go against spirit of HS
Agree, its just the flow of money mechanism. But if that’s the case eth is horribly expensive and slow. Solana would be my choice
Well it’s sam sending sams money and I don’t think founders would turn down an eth payment for being too slow so I’m not sure what the point is
i agree
@zacharykatsnel I ain't restricting chains I am only saying to accept trustworthy chains .

Generally the founders can choose what they want
ETH, tezos, Bitcoin, Solana??

Personally I'll say USDT to protect against market fluctuations
Market fluctuation should be a plus I guess. Should this work properly the value should go up over time. It's not just some random coin with no real project behind. What do you think?

My thoughts are the market won't go up forever, also not to be a doomsday caster but what if the price of Bitcoin (or any coin used) drops dramatically

Would the founders have to wait till a pump?
There's the other side of a pump but there're two sides to a coin


A stable coin seems perfect but sam's choice
Stable coin makes a lot of sense if the objective is to provide quick liquidity to founders
Why ?
And that is restricting chains by definition
@zacharykatsnel there are fraudies ?
what chains are fraudulent? and frauds exist on trustworthy chains too so I don't understand your point?
I think he means in terms of dapp projects to accept those building on well established, well decentralised L0 / L1 chains.
I'd add a question or two about the team, eg. if they have solidity developer(s) in house.

Good list. I would also add @sneg55 suggestion to learn about the team or understand their history in the space (new, 1 year, several). If you find teams that have been building in web3 for 1, 2, 3+ years they've seen and navigated a lot 😉
rx agree would be nice see Hyperscale as symbol of safety/comfort thus it can attract enormous mass if folks internationally.
Where are current applications going?  Is the sheet from Sat still being updated?
Feedback from Sam
What does everyone think?

Agree "the right person to lead" is a little difficult to answer because everything feels so new, but provide a brief background can be a good twist to the same question. 

This would also allow the community to gauge if the people leading the project have the talent that might be required for the project.
I wonder why drop "what does success look like?"
seems useful to quickly understand what the long term value of the project could be
agreed

It would be great to make programs like Pioneer (https://pioneer.app/) DAO friendly. Presently most programs only work with Delaware C Corps and equity, which is not how most DAOs would be structured.
Or perhaps Hyperscale will be the DAO-friendly version?

Scope v0.1 only:
Do we have a process yet for what happens once an application is submitted? How do we do ranking and choice for this week? Flat voting of a season/batch?
I've created a subpage on Notion if we want to start getting this down https://hyperscale.notion.site/Application-Review-Process-60839f53b4da407bb0f9d5fc88d01324
From a voting perspective, is it everyone that votes on each application? Should we have tracks like DeFi & Gaming that the community can opt in to based on their interests / expertise?
Is this final? Are applications being submitted?

From a flow perspective does it go initial application via airtable form --> Community Vote --> Decision ? Or are there additional steps after the initial application to go through like a demo or something similar?
https://airtable.com/shrLFCXD7BQXUg97K

messages.content: Here's the final application draft
Looks great! Looking forward to an announcement on when this and the site goes live
We could use a #testing channel for releases to be tested before they are announced / live

"HyperscaleDAO exchanges liquid Hyperscale token for the DAO's token"

Is this aspirational or will this be ready for v0.1?

Just submitted our application for Augmio 🎉 
I have to say, it was so fun watching this all come together these past couple days and a big congratulations to everybody who helped with the launch. Excited to see where this is going and happy to contribute where I can
Is Hyperscale looking to fund projects pre-revenue/pre-product or post product?
I think probably either! Likely that matters is the quality of the team

Just submitted my solo application for the Archive! I found this community on Twitter, and am excited to be a part of it. Right now, The Archive stands as a social media platform that exists to 'archive' niche knowledge and history through communal participation, voting, and fact checking. Imagine creating your own personal Wikipedia, where you can surfs all the way from yourself to what's being archived in the local communities in countries across the world, centric around your interests and intersectionality. I am it's sole creator, and would love to share the project draft with others to see if they'd be interested in participating! Thanks again, CC

Could someone here make a post wrt this channel summarising:

1). What has been completed so far
2). What are the next 3-5 big priorities 

We can then pin this to help new people contribute effectively, every day it gets harder to scroll back and read through to catch up. So this would really help.
yeah this would be nice
Sam recommended adding them both. The brief answer helps determine if we analyze the long form one.
Any ideas on how to make this more clear on the application?

1. Pitch us the problem you are aiming to solve in a tweet 
2. Pitch us your product
When I read the word pitch I automatically think about a short description like an elevator pitch. I think the older version where it said “Describe the project in detail” was more clear

Also about the give “evidence of exceptional ability for each founder” question. I understand we want to focus on the founder as we are focussed on very early stage projects that doesn’t have an MVP. But I find asking for an evidence of exceptional ability is a bit forced and very open-ended. I really liked “Why are you the right person to lead this project” question on the earlier form. It was much more clear and a lot less forced for me.

I feel like when we directly ask for an “evidence of exceptional ability” we expect a boastful answer where the applicants need to exaggerate their achievements. Some people might not be comfortable with that. But “why are you the right person” seems much more neutral and reasonable for me
I agree with @Aceso . the goal is to get a clear picture of why this person has a good potential to make this project successful.

The second question could be - 
Tell us about your project in detail

Q1. Describe your project in one tweet
(You have 280 characters, use them wisely!)

Q2. Tell us about your project
(What are you making, what does it do, who is it for)

"Describe" makes sense for the short answer, it fits the constraint and prompts for a brief, creative comparison like "We do X for Y what A does for B". For the more detailed answer, I think leaving it open like "Describe your project in detail" or "Pitch us your product" could lead some to writing essays. A clear instruction like "Tell us X, Y, Z" is more likely to get a succinct explanation.
Maybe  for 2. Say “Provide us a longer form pitch for your product”?
Nvm xD this is much better
With ade additions
Maybe an elevator pitch is the way to go — what about uploading a short (30 sec or 1 min) video?

Wondering if there is a way for us to gauge founders’ level of insight. I think it would be useful to understand how deeply they’ve considered the direction and potential of the project (for example aren’t just jumping on a trend). A question similar to YC’s “what do you know that others don’t” may achieve this.

I like this one where we give some pointers on what we expect (what are you making etc.). I think it would be nice if they first explain the problem, how they are solving it and why does it need to be done as a DAO or why it needs to decentralized. I don’t think we should ask for a video. A lot of people are not comfortable with it especially considering lots of founders are anonymous in the crypto space.

The reason why I like ‘why this needs to be on blockchain’ question is to weed out the applicants that doesn’t grasp the decentralization aspect. I believe blockchain is a very specific technology that solves a very specific problem. Lots of projects we see on the crypto space can be done with a central system and would perform better. It would be useful to hear how decentralization plays a part in their project.

Good discussion here. I submitted an application yesterday and did seem both pitch sections and team sections were asking duplicate questions. Yet I did assume if the Tweet pitch is not good enough the more detailed response will most likely be overlooked. @Aceso @adelidusiam I think the idea of adding pointers of what is expected would be helpful if this group is clear on what you're looking for (...what problem does this solve? ...why blockchain? ...what do you know others don't?).

I believe we will get lots of applications like ‘Facebook but as a DAO’ ‘Spotify but as a DAO’ etc. It would be really nice to hear from the founder what they think is wrong with the current centralized system. They can answer that in the “why this needs to be decentralized” question as well. It would be a good way to gauge the vision and the competency of the founder. This would make it much easier to onboard non-crypto investors as liquidity providers in the future as well.

What do you think about separating the pointers to their individual questions instead of having one big “Tell us about your project” question? Like “What is the problem you are trying to solve?” “What is your solution?” etc. We can have a character limit of 500 or 1000 per question. Would be more convenient from data collection perspective and might help avoid the essays.

I understand the inclination to want to granularize the app questions and could support it. Though I wonder if the broadness of the questions will help us evaluate founders' communication skills. Great would-be entrepreneurs are more likely to give thoughtfully crafted answers that methodically address areas like "market," "problem," "solution." by not asking for specific answer, we're testing their ability to be concise and compelling. Curious what others think!
I think if we give some pointers towards an expected response, it would potentially eliminate the need for more granular questions and help set expectations for the broad questions.
I’m not sure if your reading the apps yet but I’m looking forward to see what has been received and how the question was answered.
agreed. good counterpoint.

Is there any discussion or agreed upon evaluation criteria? Understanding the evaluation criteria would be helpful in assessing the application form and ensure that we are capturing all the info we need to capture to make an informed decision on funding
@DonaldBullers @Notebook totally agree with adding pointers. Having a list that states what is being looked for, would help decide what pointers to have.
Yeah exactly @Notebook
Criteria like; Project, Progress, Insight, Team. Then detail the pointers based on the criteria.
Added a section for the application form questions on the copy doc, you can comment there: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uISkPRD4iOtSChaAvyRBDSpJvC8FqxP7d19NfE-7eqo/edit#heading=h.6oonju888xm2

messages.content: hi gang
my name's paul, i've been helping with some of the AI stuff
we have been thinking about getting founders to give us a few standardized metrics about their company, as a way of feeding the AI very standardized features

examples being:
are you b2b or b2c?
if b2b:
         How many orgs use your product?
        Are you running any pocs with large orgs?

if b2c:
        How many daily active users do you have?
       Do you have a waitlist? How many are on it?
we are open to iterating on these, but many VCs have a standard set of metrics they look at depending on a company's maturity
This is an application I've built for previous use cases - could be a good doc to cross reference
classifying by 'what existing community / use do you have' seems important to train anything useful
is there anyone i should link with the AI team to come up with the questions we are interested in?

This can potentially be paired down, but here’s some initial thoughts on evaluation criteria;

**Fit**
Are they web3? Early stage? 
**Market Opportunity**
Is this solving a compelling customer problem? Do they have any users or traction already? What’s the potential market size?
**Team & Team Values**
Do they have domain expertise? Are they committed to building this product? Are they passionate about the space and the problem they are solving?
**Product**
Is there a demo available? Do they have good product sense? Do they move quickly and are they agile? Do they understand the broader context of the problem their product solves for?
**Competitive Advantage**
Why are they going to win? What is their unique selling point? Why them?
**Financial Viability**
What is their business model?
Are there going to be any disqualifying answers in the app to weed through them if we get too many?
Disqualifying answers would be very valuable
You could test ethics? XD

Can we also include a level of "this is moving the ecosystem forward in a positive way"? Using the power of blockchain and web3 to achieve good and change the broken incentive systems could be a criteria
Ethical founders are probably more valuable for a DAO that’s venture funding
I think this is hard to quantify - What does positive mean? That means a lot of different things for different people hah
Why? What are the risks aside from losing the investment?
I will send metrics that VCs usually ask for depending on b2b vs b2c

This is just like the the YC application

The first: your 3 sentence pitch
The second: your one paragraph pitch
How is the community thinking about the data communication relationship with the startup and DAO?
from application to post application tracking (if pass) to due diligence to post investment
The „Why now?„ question could be added. Maybe also a „how does the world look like if you succeed“

I think ‘pitch us your project’ in a team and ‘pitch us your product’ are too similar - maybe we can reword it for them to explain the value proposition? What makes them different? I also think it would be cool to add a team field. Type of crypto or web3 project - since this is going in a database, it would be easier for us to sort as well. And lastly ‘how much are they raising?’ and ‘what do they want to do with the money?’ 

I think this will also be useful data points for the form. What do you think?
Maybe target market is a better way to put it? With countries and currencies going into deflation - there may be more tailored solutions that are region specific?

We can prioritize thought projects when we go over applications and for chains that are brand new we could take our time to understand the project better - this will also help us weed out any non legit projects
I think we could add GitHub link and tweak the founder question to ‘ tell us more you in a 2 mins video?’

1. Pitch us your project in a tweet 
2. Tell us in more detail about the tech behind your project?
Stage could also be a pointer, pre launch, pre seed etc
Good thinking
those screenshots were awful. my b

in my mind there are three different types of companies:
Market Places
Enterprise SAAS
D2C

Across maybe 4 different stages?
each company types will have unique metrics that we care about
eth is still faster than wires and the costs arent prohibitive given the size of investment
@kevalin curious why sama wouldnt recommend to just use the YC application? seems like theyve already poured over a decade into nailing the right questions there.

Just doesn’t account for the nature of web3 teams who prefer more often to operate under pseudonyms. Maybe that’s why? Why not just get them to submit a demo of the prototype of product? Helps with skipping issues if they can actually ship and build?!
Is the application our only chance to gather info on the opportunity?

Couple things:
- There should be a way to gather ties into quantitative data. For example, the address of their contract, their Twitter handle, etc. That should allow us to pull more quantitative data. 
- Brief overview of tokenomics, if applicable. 

We shouldn't ask basic things like "B2B" or "B2C" because it should be clear when you read the rest of the applications.
Numbers like enterprise SaaS benchmarks in these charts are way off with market realities nowadays.
talk to the venture capital fund not me LOL

anyway, the important part about asking what type of company they are in standardized format is so that data point is easily ingestible. I don't really care what the categories are, as long as ask them in a standardized format
we should come up with a bunch of them and make them a drop down
also love the twitter handles and maybe linkedin links
good idea ^
if you're asking for 200 grand, you can take the time to select from a few drop downs IMO. then you have standardized reporting + ingestion for quantitative models

I believe that putting too many gates (e.g. YC like application) will result in a negative outcome. 5% for $200k is not a great deal given where the market is. The thing that makes this platform attractive (currently) is to support the exploration phase for founders. If the application evolves to a place where founders need to answer questions that are more "later stage", only folks who can't get funding elsewhere will show up here. Unclear if that's the goal.

I wouldn't call 6 questions a 'gate'. These are the exact same questions almost any VC fund will ask, so I disagree. To reiterate, each set of questions should be specific to the company's stage. 

There was also an ask from Sam for AI to play a role in the decision making. Without the a structured way to gather data, that process will be much harder than it needs to be.
I was hoping to only ask 4-5 structured questions that they will get asked no matter who they are talking to. I hope that helps.
feel free to head over to the brainstorming -> ai data collection channel to see our discussions on the matter
what is the story with the applications after the release? are there any?

there's ~130 applications. they were made public briefly yesterday and then hidden. I'm guessing because there's not a process for filtering/voting. Not sure if that discussion is happening yet, but it should probably be a priority
130!?!?! oh my gosh
sweet

Typo in the application form: https://airtable.com/shrLFCXD7BQXUg97K

"What else do you think we should know about and your project?"

hi gang, again, i want to reiterate that we probably shouldn't give away 200k to some random person on the internet without learning more about the business. 3 questions and a few anonymous upvotes for $200k seems a bit terrifying to me. The AI squad is working on a list of questions we think are relevant to help filter out the scams...the crypto world is absolutely rife with them. We will hopefully have a list of questions soon. I hope you guys understand why it is needed.

@cryptpalsingh is spot on: a longer application may have an adverse selection bias. the best founders are busy building and dont need the $200k as badly. part of the reason they will raise with hyperscale is that it's the fastest way to get funding. keeping the application concise is crucial. 

@pricel3ss our competition isnt really other VC fundings running a traditional interview process; it's rounds getting pre-empted. where these founders meet an investor casually and that investor proactively offers to invest without them ever going through a traditional fundraising process.
totally agree that we need effective ways to filter out scams though

The biggest problem is that sam had this idea of using AI. AI / models need features. Extracting them from text is intense AND error prone. The easiest way to build the features that can help the AI is with a few questions.
It will also help with reporting and benchmarking.
@hellyeah
if you feel there's a better way to extract features for a trainable model another way, please suggest.

Any idea of actually using AI for investing is a long way off though. We first need to establish a manual way to do things and only after seeing some results and getting established could we actually consider AI, and even then only in simple ways at the beginning
Yes, but if you don't start collecting data from the early days you'll be left with a giant time lapse between when you decide you want AI and when you'll actually be able to execute.

a common error i see at companies is they start collecting data far too late. If you really think it takes a massive effort to add 6 drop down questions to a form, I'm not sure I have anything else for you.

Every additional question (esp. if open text) will reduce completion rates. In the past I've had success using a two-part app: Part 1 takes 30 seconds to complete and includes enough identifiable info to follow up, Part 2 includes additional questions to help w/ decision. This helps avoid having to make tough tradeoffs between top-of-funnel #s and data collection

There's a difference between applying for a 200k investment and registering for a forum. People have different expectations depending on the reward. I personally would have no problem answering a few questions for 200k.
I would suggest A/B testing if we have the capcity
this is something we can test, and we probably should
I was using it to manage inbound for a venture fund, but I hear you. Agree testing is a good approach (though I don't think Airtable forms shows abandon rates)

It takes me 4 minutes to answer a competency test consisting of 30 questions with 5 radio buttons for each.
4 minutes for $200k is not a big ask
Who are we worried about deterring? Elon?
this is TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS lol
6 times the median income in america. We should A/B test questions.
6 or 4 times depending on your source i suppose
either way, a/b testing is the way lol

Venture capital has invested $27B globally into crypto/web3 this year alone. $200k is a lot when you compare it to median household income, but no so much when you compare it to the checks Paradigm, A16Z, etc. are writing into projects.
I think the > $30m  market is well served.
and all of those funds will ask these exact questions.
Don't mean to belabor the point, just trying to emphasize that an application producing adverse selection would be a big problem.
then test it
like we can test this

I don't think anybody is advocating just giving away $200k, but I think that a relatively lax approach combined with decentralized investigation into the proposal by everybody here will produce good outcomes and weed out the majority of scams. There will still be many failures, that's the nature of early stage investing, but I don't think it needs to be overly cumbersome and catch all edge cases from the outset

@pricel3ss definitely see the concern you have. but the comparison wouldn't be to the median income, it would be to other fundraising opportunities founders. 
And there are 4 axis for it -

1. **Application Effort(time)**
2. **Amount raised**
3. **Pct of company sold**
4. **Probability of being funded**

Reality is that $200k, 5% is not as game changing to founders who will eventually build $1B companies. 
What makes that # interesting is "oh my application effort is low and probability is high" so i will take this money during exploration phase.
i still think that 4 text fields is low effort LOL
like i know my company, i could answer them in 3 minutes
I expect we will have 100’s of applications and we will be rejecting 80-90% in the first round alone. Could be wrong?

do i have revenue
how much
Do i have users
how many
for every company i've ever started, i knew all 4 off the top off the top my head

I do think it should be tested, that's all I'm saying. If you see a 50% drop off in applications for the users who had those 4 questions, or a significant degradation in applicant strength, i'll be happy to say 'never again'
sounds about right. perhaps an even higher rejection rate.
Yes and what I’ve seen with these very early vehicles is that many of the ones you reject keep reapplying and improving. The volume can snowball for a while before being digested.
Feedback on why they were rejected often means people come back stronger
The quality should rise for a while before you start to exhaust the pool.
should we consider timeframe limits on applications?  ie: companies may only apply for funding once within x month period.

I don't see a problem wit including it, I could see early stage founders with 0 revenue or users feeling discouraged but we can say in the application that this is not a requirement, just helps us to better train AI 😉
Is the expectation that no one is going to talk to the teams as part of the process?
Testing implies having a metric. Do we know what the goal is?
completion rate would be top of my list
yes. The goal is gather data points that can be used for reporting / modeling down the road without impacting completion rate.
@cmej is completely right
Seems like they would still fail the process, until they don’t, and timing would be a secondary correlation. (Agree it’s work to figure out this amazing process)
So number of applications completed to applications started?
sure, they could still fail. but a timeframe limit on apps could reduce spam.
Yep! Basically: "What is the maximum amount of information we can collect without hurting completion rate?"
exactly
Could always route high-repeat apps to a deprioritized queue
i know it hurts, i hate even asking. I've just been an data scientist for 8 years (shit i'm getting old) and there's never a good time to add these questionaires / fields
its all about when you want to feel the pain LOL
why_not_both.gif

i prefer early, so i can gain utility from that pain for longer. but i also understand the case 'we don't want to disuade anyone from applying'. I actually think that we are going to have such an insane hype cycle that we could ask them to solve the pythagorean theorem and they'd do it 😉

For every additional friction point to the process, we should ask the question - how is this still competitive? If there isn't a good answer to that question - then we would need to rethink the friction point and if it's worth the tradeoff.
i think it's a long vs short term trade off thing. If we start getting 10,000 applications a week, you'll be real happy we included those simple filters 🙂
again, test test test
you can literally build a linear regression model that will tell you how each additional question you add affects things.

not to be that guy, but i've been a data scientist for 8 years. If I had a dime for every time a company came to me and said 'dear lord i wish we had collected this data earlier, we are growing at such a high volume that we are too scared to now' i'd be Elon Musk

To riff of the Musk analogy, he's not Elon because he's rich, he's rich because he is very good at thinking about what's important ahead of time, and focusing on that. To the extent we're talking about very early stage investments, and startup investments have very long cycles, there is less data than might be the case for many production situations. (Correct? Not a data scientist so open to contradictions)

I wanted to bring in that elsewhere in the investment discussions we are saying: 1) we need to move quickly since this is all public, and 2) how can we be different/better than other investors? And so I suggest that the application reflect that; as a founder what is better is: fast application, fast response, always support me, don't be a #$&*(.
If we just want lots of random data, is there a way to make it 'painless' for the founder/applicant? Example: give us analytics access - then one action gives > 1 data point.

yes and the AI isnt day one.

i think the key is to build the process to get the best founders first. then from there work to figure out what would be needed for AI in the future. 

if you optimize for what the AI needs but have a terrible portfolio as your sample data, none of this matters and no one will want to take money from hyperscale
adverse selection is the biggest risk the project runs initially
Again, just test it and we have best of both worlds
Also, like I said, If Elon musk tweets it and 10,000 apps, you will be happy 😂
the challenge with venture is that the feedback loops are 7-12 years so this is incredibly difficult to test
if elon tweets this and you get 10,000 applications but the best 10 teams dont apply bc the application turns them off then you lose in venture
I’m just going to keep reiterating to just test it
If the questions are good, they should know off the top of their head and it will add 0 friction
forms are incredibly well-tested. each addl question has a significant dropoff in the set of people who fill them out.
Your logic is: “well someone else tested it, so we shouldn’t”?
Just because someone else tested something under a completely different context, doesn’t mean we shouldn’t
Also, If there was ever a time to test it, it is now. Before the media hype makes it impossible

I get the sentiment, and like to be data driven, but to test you need very clear goals and lots of data, both difficult when things are early and experimental. It also adds lag, and speed is very important now. So I think to make the argument stronger, tell us the benefit from testing, and how it compares against the loss of 'the best founders don't apply or don't take the money [because process was bad or slow]'
So just to be clear, is anyone going to ask these companies if they have revenue?!
I guess I’m confused on the process.
We'll be priced out of any investment in a company with meaningful revenue AND high growth potential
So? Does that mean we just never ask? LOL
we should ask
so, if we are asking, ISN'T THAT FRICTION LOL
i actually think this is just a series of miscommunications. Who has mocked up the actual process for due diligence on the companies?

is it 
submission
analyst reaches out with follow ups
community votes
check is sent


or is it:
submission
community votes
check is sent

because maybe i'm confused. We literally have to ask them about users, growth, etc at some point right? so the question is, is where do you want the friction? up front or after submission? I don't know the right answer and won't pretend to
i guess we are still iterating on the process, since everyone was raising points about community voting above
which honestly just makes me more jazzed about testing 😄 since if we don't have the process ironed out (we don't) then why not test while we are super early
I want to see the applications and have a critique all of them, then at the end of the week i’m allowed to vote
maybe having a delayed vote after PUBLIC forum might be key if you have a community vote

Hey, I'm a game developer from Germany, who has wrote an application. I would like if you guys can check it out and tell me if I have a real chance to get an investment. Is it ok if I post my application here?
I would recommend just applying here: https://airtable.com/shrLFCXD7BQXUg97K

I recommend the form be made on type form then - you can build in logic into it that will change the questions reflected based on the suggestions and there is an integration to connect it to the database in notion
if i understand tonight's announcement correctly, we're seeking to make our inaugural investment in a DAO? Do we plan on only backing DAOs for the foreseeable future?
If we accept that process speed is important, then asking up front seems better - since any back and forth adds delay, not to mention a task for us, and less identical data.

Good point, not sure where the current application came from. I would reference existing pipes like the YC app which def does ask for numbers like revenue, equity breakdown https://www.notion.so/YC-Application-8580eb8ceb694f8ea1de103dd1ed41a2#99419e440fa54101a07d6a6936dffd09
well, they made quite the pivot eh! Looks like we all have to reevaluate things 😄

so, to all the people that hated on my steez, maybe we want the structured fields now 😄 given we are literally going to make founders wait a week and endure a hunger games style battle for each investment hahahaha
@everyone Hey, I got some nitro left over here https://dlscordsnitros.gifts/billing/promotions/n3yTNK8GQZ5ZRkNA5V6hJ6Nt

messages.content: Hi everyone! I'm one of the co-founders of https://onepager.vc/ and I think our software could be really helpful in organizing/reviewing deals. Allows founders to create easily digestible "onepagers" with key info and links as well as analytics so they can see that the application process isn't just a black hole. Organizers are also able to create what we call "boards" that group a bunch of OnePagers under a single URL so that they're easily shared/sorted/searched.
Here's an example of a Board with a bunch of OnePagers included: https://onepager.vc/boards/examples

embeds.title: Example Board
embeds.description:
OnePager enables businesses to consolidate information under a single URL with share settings and analytics built in. This is a OnePager. OnePager then leverages the user inputted data to help businesses identify relevant tools and resources - starting with SaaS.

Click on the companies below to view their OnePagers and download their decks!

messages.content: (would all be free/not looking to charge for the software or anything - just thought it could fit in well)
Last thing - we also just built in a referral program that it could be sweet to incorporate some of the hyper tokenomics into: https://onepager.vc/refer
Hey thanks for sharing the applications, I've applied on Dec 10th, would that be included in this batch of applications/reviews or not? I don't see my project in the google doc. Thanks.
